thread.title: Outdoors calendar, week beginning Saturday, Oct. 17
thread.title_full: Outdoors calendar, week beginning Saturday, Oct. 17

author: AD CRABLE & P.J. REILLY
title: Outdoors calendar, week beginning Saturday, Oct. 17
text:
Duck season opens Saturday in many parts of Pennsylvania. Outdoors calendar, week beginning Saturday, Oct. 17 AD CRABLE & P.J. REILLY 
Duck season opens Saturday in many parts of Pennsylvania. 
SATURDAY 
Pa. duck season opens in South Zone. Runs through October 24. 
Pa. hunting seasons open for squirrels and ruffed grouse. 
Family Fall Fest at Exelon’s Muddy Run Recreation Park. 11:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m. For more information, call 284-5850. 
Rambling About on a Riparian Tree Walk, 2-3 p.m., at Central Park. For all ages. Meet at Rockford Road at the west end of the floodplain below Rockford Plantation. Join naturalist Andy Yoder for a tour exploring what riparian means and enjoy the replanting efforts of several volunteer groups and the county’s own facilities management team on the Conestoga floodplain below Rockford Plantation. This area is home to a variety of beautiful tree species. These trees and shrubs love the deep, moist soil in the floodplain and help stabilize the stream bank and provide needed cover and food for wildlife in the riparian zone. There is a $1 fee per person. Preregistration required by calling 295-2055. 
Fun with Autumn Leaves program, 10 a.m.-noon, Pavilion 2 in Central Park. For all ages. Spend a crisp autumn morning with naturalist Tina Mark. Visitors will be taking a walk and collecting various leaves to use in several craft projects. Participants can make a sun-catcher, a placemat, leaf rubbing or make your own unique picture to remember the day. Please dress for the weather and wear comfortable shoes for walking over uneven ground. Bring a bag for leaf collecting, a clothes iron and old bath towel — 100 percent cotton if possible (they will be available to share if you don’t have any). There is a fee $3 per crafter; $1 per helper. Children must be accompanied by an adult and children 3 and under are free. Preregistration required by calling 295-2055. 
Beginner Woodcarving class, 9 a.m. - 2 p.m., Environmental Center in Central Park. For ages 14 and up. Learn the basics of woodcarving during this beginner class taught by members of the Lancaster County Woodcarvers Association. The course will cover different knife cuts, knife sharpening techniques and carving safety. Participants will get to carve their own hedgehog. All participants must purchase a cut-proof glove at the beginning of the class for $8 or bring your own. Bring a light lunch as we will take a 30-minute break. All materials, including loaner knives, will be available. Carving knives will also be on sale. Call 295-2055 to register. There is a $3 fee per person. 
Owl Prowl: From 6-8:15 p.m. at Wild Birds Unlimited, 1947 Fruitville Pike. Registration required by calling 208-6881. 
Wildlife artist Gerald W. Putt exhibit opens at Olewine Gallery at Ned Smith Center for Nature & Arts, 176 Water Company Road, Millersburg. Exhibit runs through December 19. Admission is $7 for adults, $2 for seniors and free for members and children under 12. 
Northeast Lancaster City Street Tree Planting at Ross Street United Methodist Church, 312 Ross St., from 8:30 a.m. - 1 p.m. Volunteers are needed to plant approximately 28 street trees. For more information, contact Andrew Whalen, awwhalen@yahoo.com . 
Trapshooting practice for public: Conewago Rod & Gun Club, Elizabethtown. From 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Call 426-2016 or visit conewagogunclub.org . 
SUNDAY 
One-day-only auto tour of St. Anthony's Wilderness on State Game Lands 211 in Dauphin and Lebanon counties. Tour will be from 9 a.m.-3 p.m. from the Ellendale gate, 7 miles east of the borough of Dauphin, north of Harrisburg. Cars will drive one-way for 17 miles on an abandoned railroad bed through the Stony Creek Valley, exiting onto Goldmine Road in Lebanon County. Pennsylvania Game Commission staff will be on hand along the way. 
Lean Your Trees program at Gov. Dick Park , 2 p.m., Environmental Center, off Pinch Road near Mt. Gretna. Includes a naturalist foray and tree identification walk. Pre-register by calling 964-3808; or email governordick@hotmail.com . Leave name and phone number in case program cancels. 
Field trip to Hawk Mountain Sanctuary , led by Quittapahilla Audubon Society. Leaves 9 a.m. from McDonald’s (east side of Lebanon). We will spend late morning and early afternoon at the hawk watch lookout and return no later than 4 p.m. This is the peak migration time for accipiters. Bring lunch, water and dress for the weather and wear hiking boots. There is a $7 trail fee for non-members. Open to the public. Leader Jim Fiorentino, 269-0675. www.QASAudubon.org . 
Hike for public, led by Lancaster Hiking Club. At 1:15 p.m., hike 5.5 miles at Kane Park and Lake Williams. Meet to carpool at the corner of Race and Buchanan avenues at Buchanan Park in Lancaster. 
Sporting clays shoot: Atglen Sportsmen. From 8 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.; $12. The club is on Creek Road, west of Atglen, in Sadsbury Township, Lancaster County. 
Indoor handgun shoot: Mill Creek Sportsmen’s Association, from noon-2:30 p.m. Nonmembers, $15. Call 393-6416. Handgun safety course available. 
MONDAY 
Donegal Fish and Conservation Association meets, 7 p.m., at Donegal Presbyterian Church, 1891 Donegal Springs Road, Mount Joy. 
Meeting: Lititz Sportsmen Association, 7:30 p.m. at the American Legion, 109 N.Broad St., Lititz. 
Practice trap shoot: Paradise Sportsman’s Association. From 5-7 p.m.; $4. Take Route 741 east from Strasburg; right on Belmont Road. 
TUESDAY 
Millcreek Sportsmen’s Association meets, 7:30 p.m., 1877 Windy Hill Road. For more information, call (717) 393-6416. 
Aquarium Club of Lancaster County meets, 7:30 p.m. at Hempfield United Methodist Church, 3050 Marietta Ave. (corner of Marietta Ave and Stoney Battery Road). For more information, call Dave Frehafer, 626-9456. 
Practice trap shoot: Southern Lancaster County Farmer-Sportsmen. From 1-8:30 p.m.; $4. Take Route 272 south to Buck; left on Route 372; left on Hollow Road. 
WEDNESDAY 
Jump into More Science Fun program for kids 3-8, 10 a.m.-11 a.m. or 11:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. at the Environmental Center in Central Park. Naturalist Mary Ann Schlegel leads. This week’s program: Falling Leaves. Explore changing seasons with books, activities and crafts. Dress for indoor crafts and outdoor play. Younger children with parents are welcome to attend if accompanying older siblings. Call (717) 295-2055 by noon Tuesday the day prior to the program. There is a fee of $3 per child age 3 and up; $1 per adult. 
Sporting clays shoot: Atglen Sportsmen. Begin at 5 p.m. $5.50. The club is on Creek Road, Sadsbury Township. 
Trap shoots under the lights: Adamstown Rod & Gun Club. Begins at 5 p.m.; $3. The club is at 563 Willow St., Reinholds. 
Trap shoot: Columbia Fish & Game. From 6-8 p.m. Take Route 30 west; right on Prospect Road; left on Fairview Road. 
Sporting clays shoot, Elstonville Sportsmen. From 4-7 p.m. Take Route 72 north from Manheim; left on Pinch Road. 
THURSDAY 
Pa. firearms antlerless deer season for junior and senior license holders. Through Saturday. 
Southern Lancaster County Farmers Sportsmen’s cowboy fast-draw shooting practice: from 6-8 p.m. Take Route 272 south to Buck; left on Route 372; left on Hollow Road. 
UPCOMING 
Pa. hunting seasons for pheasants and rabbits open Saturday, Oct. 24. Run through Nov. 28. 
Hiker Badge for Brownie Girl Scouts , 10 a.m. - noon, at the Environmental Center, Saturday, October 24. Naturalist Mary Ann Schlegel will lead Brownie Girl Scouts in completing badge requirements which include learning about trail signs, maps and gear before heading off on a hike. Leaders must provide the snack/gorp. Dress for the weather and wear appropriate shoes for a hike on woodland trails. Please register and prepay by Wednesday, Oct. 21. Cost is $5 per Scout; $1 per adult; badges are not included. Call (717) 295-2055 to register. 
Susquehanna Heritage Stories of the Susquehanna series will be held on Wednesday, Nov. 11, from 6:30-8:30 p.m. Jack Brubaker leads talk on his book, “Down the Susquehanna to the Chesapeake.” Light refreshments will be provided. Susquehanna Heritage is located at 1706 Long Level Road, Wrightsville. Each lecture is $10 per person; advanced registration is required. Call (717) 252-0229, ext. 6; or email: info@SusquehannaHeritage.org . 
Special deer hunts at Middle Creek Wildlife Management Area , Wednesday, Dec. 16 and Wednesday, Jan. 13. Two limited archery/flintlock muzzleloader hunts for antlerless deer. A public drawing will be held at the Middle Creek Wildlife Management Area Visitors Center at 10 a.m. on Wednesday, November 4. There will be only one drawing to fill both hunting days. The first 100 applications drawn will be assigned to the hunt on Dec. 16, the second 100 to hunt on Jan. 13. Successful applicants will be notified by mail. Applications must be on a standard postcard, obtained at a U.S. Post Office, and contact the following information: hunter name; complete mailing address; hunting license number (CID number); and antlerless deer license number for Wildlife Management Unit 5B (if applicable). Only one application per hunter may be submitted. Applications will be accepted, by may only, until Nov. 2, and must be mailed to: Pennsylvania Game Commission MCWMA; P. O. Box 110; Kleinfeltersville, PA 17039. 
Those who plan to purchase their first hunting license this year will need to make plans to attend a Hunter-Trapper Education course , and classes are being held at locations across the state, according to the Pennsylvania Game Commission. Because the fall hunting seasons- and the corresponding rush for new hunter to become certified- still are months away, it can be easier to find a class now compared to later in the year. Plus, those who complete the class now, still have time to buy a license and hunt in the upcoming spring gobbler season, and will be able to apply for a 2015-16 antlerless deer license before they sell out. To register for a course in your area, visit GoHuntPA.org and click on “Learn to Hunt” link, or go to the Game Commissioner’s website (www.pgc.state.pa.us), and click on “Hunter Education Classes” icon in the center of the homepage. From here, you can elect to take the basic “Hunter-Trapper Education” course, which is typically a six-hour course held over one or two days. Persons 16 years of age or older also may elect to take a new fully online Hunter-Trapper education course, which also takes six hours to complete. Those who are certified through online course must pay a $19.50 fee upon completion. Successful completion of a basic Pennsylvania Hunter-Trapper Education class, or another state’s equivalent course, is required by state law to obtain a first-time hunting or furtaker license, regardless of age. In addition, registrations are being accepted for other educational programs offered by the Game Commission, including Successful Turkey Hunting, Successful Bowhunting, Successful Furtaking and Bowhunting, Successful Furtaking and Cable Restraint Certifications. The Success Turkey Hunting course is designed to provide the knowledge and skills needed to hunt safely and confidently in both spring and fall seasons. Veterans will learn methods and techniques that will help them become better hunters. Student will receive a 140-page student guide and a diaphragm ticket call as part of the program. Classes started this spring and continue through the summer and early fall. A $15 fee is being charged to offset the costs. The Successful Bowhunting course is a one-day voluntary training program for those seeking to expand their skills and knowledge of bowhunting. Although Pennsylvania doesn’t require archers to complete a bowhunting education course before they purchase an archery license, certification for this course is required to bowhunt in some other states. There is a $20 course fee, which covers the cost of the online study course required before attending the class. Successful Furtaking is one-day training program that provides extensive hands-on training to new and experienced furtakers. The course promotes Best Management Practices and is designed for any person seeking to learn more about furtaking and to improve his or her skills and success. The course includes the cable-restraint certification that is required to participate in Pennsylvania’s cable-restraint season for foxes and coyotes. This course also fulfills the requirement that all first-time furtaker license buyers pass either a basic trapper education course or basic Pennsylvania HTE course. A $15 course fee is charged. The Cable Restraint Certification course is required for those trappers seeking to participate in Pennsylvania’s annual trapping season in which cable restraints are used to capture coyotes and foxes. The course fee is $15, and students get to keep various education materials and one legal cable restraint provided as part of the course. 
The Outdoors Calendar welcomes information on hunting, fishing, hiking and other outdoors event. E-mail details to acrable@lnpnews.com ; fax to 399-6507; send to Ad Crable, PO Box 1328, Lancaster, Pa 17608-1328; or call 481-6029. More Headlines
